thread.title: ‘He looks like he’s a woodchopper for fun’
thread.title_full: ‘He looks like he’s a woodchopper for fun’

title: ‘He looks like he’s a woodchopper for fun’
text:
THERE are many ways for footballers to endear themselves to supporters. 
Kicking a few goals is one way, putting in a dominant showing is another. 
But there’s nothing quite like laying out an opposition player with a fair bump to get the home fans on side. 
North Melbourne’s Braydon Preuss did all three in front of a vocal Arden Street crowd on Sunday in a performance that is bound to earn him consideration for a Round 1 debut. 
The imposing young ruckman, who stands at 206cm and 109kg, collected 27 hit-outs and kicked three goals in the 21-point win over Hawthorn, combining well with All-Australian Todd Goldstein to give Kangaroos coach Brad Scott something to think about going into the season. 
But while the fans at North Melbourne’s spiritual home enjoyed what he produced around the ground, nothing left them more excited than a bone-rattling bump on Hawthorn’s Liam Shiels in the first term. 
It was that physicality — something which former captain Andrew Swallow was already familiar with — that is already seeing Preuss gain a cult following around the club. 
And while Goldstein, arguably the AFL’s most dominant ruckman over the last two seasons, has preferred a role as the side’s sole big man, Preuss’ ability to be thrown forward and be a scoreboard threat has left many thinking the pair can work in tandem. 
Live stream EVERY game of the JLT Community Series on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW > 
Indeed, even Goldstein himself is a believer in their new-found partnership. 
“It’s always nice to have someone like Braydon come in,” Goldstein told foxfooty.com.au . 
“I think we showed today that we can play pretty well together and we can impact the game in different ways. If the coaches want to go down that way, it’s a good combination.” 
Together, the duo combined for 45 hit-outs — limiting Hawthorn’s big men to only 19 between them — while their impact in numerous positions around the ground was influential. 
“Braydon’s been great this pre-season and he’s carrying that confidence forward,” Goldstein said. 
“I’ve seen him develop and grow for the last three or four years and he’s worked so hard. For someone of his size, he’s going to be very hard to move. 
“I’ve seen him work very hard and it’s no surprise, he deserves all of the credit he’s getting at the moment.” 
Preuss’ breakout display on Sunday came off the back of a promising showing as the sole ruckman in last week’s victory over Sydney. 
In Coffs Harbour, the 21-year-old collected 29 hit-outs in the absence of Goldstein, establishing himself as a genuine contender for an early season senior debut. Preuss' hitout win % is the 2nd highest of any ruckman to play in the #JLTSeries so far. Gawn's is the 3rd lowest. #SuperCoach #AFLFantasy — Fantasy Freako (@FantasyFreako) February 26, 2017 
“He was really strong last week taking the No. 1 ruck mantle and today he and Goldy chopped and changed and he played up forward,” North’s stand-in coach Josh Drummond said. 
“It’s a great problem to have — it’s what you want. That’s what the pre-season is for, to give those young guys a chance and he’s one who has certainly stepped up. 
“They’re both probably No.1 ruck types, in terms of them being genuine ruckmen, but he gave us something to think about with the way he played up forward.” 
But while North Melbourne has favoured a one-ruck system in recent years, Preuss’ ability to have an impact up forward gives the coaching staff something to think about. 
His three goals on Sunday were the result of two strong marks inside 50, as well as a clean pick-up and snap below his knees. 
“It’s a challenge for all of our guys budding for those ruck spots,” Drummond said. 
“The way the game is now with the limited interchange, you need guys to be flexible. 
“We haven’t had too much of a look at him up forward, so it was great for him to get that opportunity today. He took a couple of nice marks and looked dangerous. 
“They don’t go on trees, those big fellas, so it’s good to have a couple up and going and give us something to think about.” 
But if Preuss’ form on the field is a plus, his development into a newly established fan favourite is a bonus — with supporters at Arden Street loving his attack on the footy. 
“This bloke has been one of the finds of the JLT Community Series,” Gerard Healy said on Fox Footy’s coverage. 
“It’s great when you see new talent coming in and new talent having a physical impact. 
“He looks like he is a woodchopper for fun.” View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
